notes.text:
Red Hat OpenShift Enterprise release 2.2.9, which fixes several 
security issues, several bugs, and introduces feature enhancements, is 
now available.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having Important
security impact. Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base
scores, which give detailed severity ratings, are available for each
vulnerability from the CVE links in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
OpenShift Enterprise by Red Hat is the company's cloud computing
Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) solution designed for on-premise or
private cloud deployments.

The following security issue is addressed with this release:

It was found that ActiveMQ did not safely handle user supplied data 
when deserializing objects. A remote attacker could use this flaw to 
execute arbitrary code with the permissions of the ActiveMQ 
application. (CVE-2015-5254)

An update for Jenkins Continuous Integration Server that addresses a 
large number of security issues including XSS, CSRF, information 
disclosure and code execution have been addressed as well. 
(CVE-2015-5317, CVE-2015-5318, CVE-2015-5319, CVE-2015-5320, 
CVE-2015-5321, CVE-2015-5322, CVE-2015-5323, CVE-2015-5324, 
CVE-2015-5325, CVE-2015-5326, CVE-2015-7537, CVE-2015-7538, 
CVE-2015-7539, CVE-2015-8103)

Space precludes documenting all of the bug fixes in this advisory. See
the OpenShift Enterprise Technical Notes, which will be updated
shortly for release 2.2.9, for details about these changes:

https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/OpenShift_Enterprise/2/html-single/Technical_Notes/index.html

All OpenShift Enterprise 2 users are advised to upgrade to these 
updated packages.
notes.title: Details

notes.text: It was found that use of a JMS ObjectMessage does not safely handle user supplied data when deserializing objects. A remote attacker could use this flaw to execute arbitrary code with the permissions of the application using a JMS ObjectMessage.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: ObjectMessage: unsafe deserialization
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: A malicious message producer needs to authenticate to EAP in order to send messages. Also, the use of JMS ObjectMessage needs to be chosen by the developer of the application. Therefore this issue is rated as moderate.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released 
errata relevant to your system have been applied.

See the OpenShift Enterprise 2.2 Release Notes, which will be 
updated shortly for release 2.2.9, for important instructions on how 
to fully apply this asynchronous errata update:

https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/OpenShift_Enterprise/2/html-single/2.2_Release_Notes/index.html#chap-Asynchronous_Errata_Updates

This update is available via the Red Hat Network. Details on how to use
the Red Hat Network to apply this update are available at: 
https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

If you do deploy a JMS publisher, and subscriber, and don't trust the messages sent to you by your clients, you could mitigate this issue by installing a Java agent which restricts the classes which can be deserialized. This is an article with the recommended approach:

https://access.redhat.com/solutions/2190911

You could also mitigate this issue using the features of the Java Virtual Machine added in JEP 290:

http://openjdk.java.net/jeps/290

notes.text: The Fingerprints pages in Jenkins before 1.638 and LTS before 1.625.2 might allow remote attackers to obtain sensitive job and build name information via a direct request.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: jenkins: Project name disclosure via fingerprints (SECURITY-153)
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

notes.text: Jenkins before 1.638 and LTS before 1.625.2 uses a publicly accessible salt to generate CSRF protection tokens, which makes it easier for remote attackers to bypass the CSRF protection mechanism via a brute force attack.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: jenkins: Public value used for CSRF protection salt (SECURITY-169)
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

notes.text: XML external entity (XXE) vulnerability in the create-job CLI command in Jenkins before 1.638 and LTS before 1.625.2 allows remote attackers to read arbitrary files via a crafted job configuration that is then used in an "XML-aware tool," as demonstrated by get-job and update-job.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: jenkins: XXE injection into job configurations via CLI (SECURITY-173)
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

notes.text: Jenkins before 1.638 and LTS before 1.625.2 do not properly verify the shared secret used in JNLP slave connections, which allows remote attackers to connect as slaves and obtain sensitive information or possibly gain administrative access by leveraging knowledge of the name of a slave.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: jenkins: Secret key not verified when connecting a slave (SECURITY-184)
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

vulnerabilities.title: jenkins: Jenkins plugin manager vulnerable to MITM attacks (SECURITY-234)

notes.text: The Jenkins CLI subsystem in Jenkins before 1.638 and LTS before 1.625.2 allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted serialized Java object, related to a problematic webapps/ROOT/WEB-INF/lib/commons-collections-*.jar file and the "Groovy variant in 'ysoserial'".
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: jenkins: Remote code execution vulnerability due to unsafe deserialization in Jenkins remoting (SECURITY-218)
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released 
errata relevant to your system have been applied.

See the OpenShift Enterprise 2.2 Release Notes, which will be 
updated shortly for release 2.2.9, for important instructions on how 
to fully apply this asynchronous errata update:

https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/OpenShift_Enterprise/2/html-single/2.2_Release_Notes/index.html#chap-Asynchronous_Errata_Updates

This update is available via the Red Hat Network. Details on how to use
the Red Hat Network to apply this update are available at: 
https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258
